column4: sans-serif" COLOR="#000080" SIZE="+1">Hilton of Cadboll Pictish Cross-slab

column1: Hilton of Cadboll Cross Slab
©1995-2007 Gazetteer for Scotland

Lying to the north of Hilton of Cadboll on the Moray Firth coast of Easter Ross is a replica of a 9th Century Pictish Cross-slab. This finely carved stone portrays a complex and unique design of a female aristocrat
column2: hunting on horseback. This potentially illustrates the senior position of women in Pictish society. The stone was broken when found and further defaced in the 17th Century to make a grave-stone
column3:
although never used for this purpose.

In the late 19th Century
column4: the original was initially removed by the local laird to decorate his garden at Invergordon Castle. Just after the First World War
column5: when the castle was to be sold
column6: the stone was given to the British Museum in London. However there were demands for it to be returned to Scotland and in 1921 it was given to the Royal Scottish Museum in Edinburgh. The slab is now displayed in the Museum of Scotland. In a project supported by Historic Scotland
column7: a replacement stone (weighing 7 tonnes) was carved and unveiled in September 2000
column8: close to the site of the original. In 2001 excavations revealed the bottom section of the original slab
column9: together with a number of other fragments
column10:
which will provide vital information about the designs destroyed on the larger section.

A local campaign has ensured these fragments will remain in the village.
